position.marginalia_text: Joannes Damascenus, qui uixit te[m]pore Theodosij, et Vale[n]tiniani Imp. habuit apud se discipulu[m] Persicu[m], que[m] diligeter erudiebat. Is finxit epistola[m] nomine Jo. Damasceni, cuius manu[m] imitari poterat, hoc argume[n]to: Ego Jo. Damascenus significo Regi persico, ut, si uelit, ueniat: iam posse cu[m] capere Imp. Vale[n]tinianu[m], proper alias atq[ue] alias occasiones. Ha[e]c epistola
spargebat[u]r in Aula Regis perfici; qua[m] sibi oblatu[m], mox Imperatori misit. Imp. ad se uocans Damascenu[m] mo[n]strauit illi Literas, rogauitq[ue] quare scripsisset,

eam negare: sed sanctè iuro, me nihil unq[uam] tale cogitasse, nedu[m] scripsisse. Cui Imp: no[n] potes negare: manus est tua: Ità homo victus, dextra manu est mutilatus. Talem Talem pra[e]ceptori gratiam vafer discipulus reposuit.

in his name An Eloquent , & witty Apology of Buggery: as on speciall work of his famous eloquence, & Lerning.
A spytefull & perillous Deuise: euen as diuellish in a manner, as [the] Diuel himself.

book.title: Galateo: The Rules of Polite Behavior

position.marginalia_text: If he had karried [the] lyke grudg against [the] pope, he woold not haue steekid, to haue published his villanous booke, De Tribus Impostoribus Mundi, in his name: such spritish deseignes, & practises had peter Aretine, to fulfill his owne phantasticall moode, and to purchase A deepe conceyte of his inco[m]perable & mystical singularity. Vlisses, practise against Palamedis, sumwhat in [the] lyk kynde, & nolesse cunninge.

marginalia.translation: John of Damascus, who lived in the time of the emperors Theodosius and Valentian, had among himself a Persian disciple, whom he educated diligently. That disciple forged a letter with the name of John of Damascus, whose hand he could imitate, with this indication: I, John of Damascus, show to the Persian king that, if he wishes, he should come. Since it is already possible to capture emperor Valentian, on one occasion after the other. This letter was scattered in the palace of the Persian king, which, having been presented to himself, soon he sent to the emperor. The emperor summoned John of Damascus to him, pointed out the letter to him, and asked why he had written it. John of Damascus, inspecting it diligently, said: "Lord emperor, I recognise my hand, nor can I deny this letter. But by the holy law, I never thought neither wrote such a thing." To which the emperor [replied]: "You cannot deny [this]: it is your hand." Thus the man was defeated and his right hand was cut off. The crafty disciple repaid such thanks to his teacher.
